Looks like it is over.  Next election is in June, but how many voters will show up?

Last I heard, the King was not planning to put out another name for PM.  Since he's the only one who can do that, and since he has no more playdates scheduled with the party leaders, this is effectively over, although it does have to be held for the constitutional deadline so he can officially call for new elections.   It is doubtful he'll brook any more meetings with the kids unless he is somewhat more than 100 percent certain of a real live no-kidding ironclad permanent irrevocable deal.  Not happening.  The elections announcement will, inshallah, finally close this issue unless we're supposed to keep answering the same question to guess about those new elections that upcome in June.  I gather from the last attempted clarification that this isn't going to be the case, but my confidence is shaky at this point.

With around 80 percent of voters indicating that they wanted a coalition government and not a repeat election, participation is likely to plummet." Spain will not ask for coalition discussion.  Spain has new election  Spain to Hold New Elections After Coalition Talks Fail
By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS MADRID — King Felipe VI of Spain decided on Tuesday that none of the country’s political parties had enough support to form a government, setting the stage for an election in June, six months after voters ended the nation’s traditional two-party system. The king announced his decision after spending two days meeting with party leaders, including those in charge of the conservative Popular Party, the center-left Socialists, the far-left Podemos party and the business-friendly Ciudadanos party. His decision means that no party will be able to assemble a minority or coalition government that would assume control of the 350-member lower house of Parliament by May 2 and sets up a new election for June 26. Spain has been politically paralyzed since its national election on Dec. 20, in which Podemos and Ciudadanos emerged as strong No. 3 and No. 4 parties, after decades of alternating rule between the Popular Party and the Socialists.

The King says he hasn't got anybody to propose as PM, so new elections are constitutionally inevitable. They have not yet been officially called; as I understand it (always a tenuous basis on which to proceed) they are required to play out the clock, which runs until 03 May.  There is a theoretical chance of a last-minute deal, but the acrimony is waist-high in Madrid these days. The Q will probably not be closed until an official announcement, but going to 100% on Neither is as safe a bet as can be imagined without drugs.

this Q should be closed now: MADRID—Spain will hold a repeat of national elections in June following the failure Tuesday of a last-ditch effort by King Felipe VI to prod bickering Spanish politicians to form a new government.
King Felipe chose not to ask any candidates he interviewed this week to try to form a government and break a stalemate that has left Spain with a caretaker government in the wake of inconclusive elections in December. The meetings, the third round of talks the king has held with political leaders, were the last chance to come to some kind of agreement before a May 2 deadline. But the conversations only resulted in further recriminations among the party leaders, who blamed each other for making Spain ungovernable. Late Tuesday, the monarch said Article 99 of Spain’s constitution would take effect. That calls for the dissolution of parliament and new elections if no government is formed two months after the first parliamentary vote on seating one. The new elections will be held on June 26.

TO RECAP THE SITUATION:  http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2016/03/24/three-key-choices-facing-spain-as-the-country-continues-to-search-for-its-next-government/ As a result of the election December 20th . . .
". . . .the People’s Party (PP) under the leadership of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy [went] from an absolute majority of 186 seats (out of 350), . . .  to a plurality of 123, losing one third of its voters on the way. On top of this, the proliferation of corruption scandals around the party, and four years without proper dialogue between the PP and the opposition, have made it impossible for Rajoy to strike a deal with any other party to get elected as Prime Minister again. Knowing that his chances of getting voted by the Parliament were null, he went as far as rejecting the call from the King to try to form a government. It seemed safer, at least at that time, to see his Socialist opponent fail in the attempt instead of him. "The new centrist-liberal party, Ciudadanos, as well as a number of relevant Socialists, have made it clear that no agreement is possible with the conservatives if Rajoy does not step down, but the proposal has been rebuffed by Rajoy and it seems not to have made inroads among the PP high brass. The PP likes to present itself as a strong, unified party in which leaderships are uncontested and internal conflict inexistent. So the People’s Party has to make a choice it has never before faced: it can lose a relatively damaged Rajoy and use its plurality to lead a coalition government, or it can keep Rajoy and its aura of being a monolithic, strong party. "The Socialist Party (PSOE) also faces a difficult choice between two options that had never been incompatible before. The Socialists have been in government for 21 years since 1982,  . . . . At the same time, since 1996 (the year in which the conservatives first won the general election), it has consistently built its identity as the alternative to the People’s Party – a strategy that has enabled the Socialists to mobilise their own electoral base and encourage tactical voting among leftists in general. "Both principles used to be easy to blend, but not anymore. A deal with Podemos, the new anti-austerity party, would allow Pedro Sánchez to succeed Rajoy as Prime Minister, but it would alienate those that appreciate the Socialists as a reliably centrist party. Any coalition with the PP, on the other hand, would have the opposite effect. Moreover, because this dilemma has been enacted by internal fractions, Sánchez’s room for manoeuvre has been substantially reduced. "Felipe VI, the new king enthroned in June 2014, is also sailing in uncharted waters. In Spain, as in other parliamentary monarchies, the King reigns but he does not rule. . . . With four major parties, none of them even close to absolute majority, and no two-party coalition short of a grand coalition big enough to reach that same threshold, the arbiter can tip the balance one way or another. "Furthermore, there seems to be a trade-off between the King keeping his role as a neutral institutional anchor that does not interfere with political decisions, which appears to be the patch he has chosen to take, and his capacity to take brisker action and hasten the process in a more proactive way. The decision to make it public that Rajoy had turned down the King’s offer to form a new government, followed by the decision to make that same offer to Pedro Sánchez, followed by the decision, after the latter’s failure, not to make any other offer before conditions have changed, has probably minimised the pressure upon parties to strike a deal, and at the same time has preserved his supra-partes status. At the same time, however, the fact that it is taking months to elect a prime minister might be taking a toll on Spain’s institutions. Again, an uncomfortable, unprecedented decision for a key actor. ~~~~~~~

Podemos recently changed their Organization's Secretary, in a "not very polite way", they sacked Sergio Pascual and replaced him with Echenique. This may change things in favour of Podemos in the scenario of "new ways to talks" for understanding both outside and inside the organization. Podemos was bleeding support in both ways, externally and internally, but Pablo Iglesias (Podemos presidential candidate and also general secretariat)  made a surprising movement (for the good) with this change, not of person, but on way of thinking. Echenique, together with Teresa Rodríguez, were the only ones to confront Pablo Iglesias in the running for the head of the political party. Pablo Iglesias team thought that a "electoral war machine" (a kind of aggressive and vertical way of manage the relations internally and externally) were the path to get it right in the elections, it was not on the long run.  The basis, the "core" of the initial support, the quincemayistas (people that massively rise against government on may 15th 2011) were clearly against this way of managing the political party, a traditional way of "master and command" which was precisely what the people protested about. But Pablo Iglesias was a media popular talk show guest at the time of the election and their number two Errejón (and presumably Pablo Iglesias as well) thought that TV talk shows were enough to win both the people and the election.  That might be truth at the beginning, but was clearly the wrong path for the future, as the "basis" or the core, in a political party are the "engine of hope" and the ones that stick the political banners on the walls, and those "basis" voted with a sick feeling as "there is no other better option" in past December elections. But time passed by and the selfishness continued, and that was enough for many. Voting poll consistently showed a decline in vote intention and people started to leave. But now, things are starting to be different, Echenique's appointment, a man with a consensus mind, a scientific with non false humility manners, may be the man to re-joint forces, internally and externally. His appointment must be ratified by the Citizen's Council of Podemos, and I foresee wide support. That is why I changed my forecast positively towards and advance in the chances of Podemos to form part of a new hypothetical government, and I also forecast a rise in the polls vote intention in http://elelectoral.com/encuesta-media/ (average of polls vote intention of different sources). On the other side, a new PSOE's congress that changes their leadership from Pedro to Susana and also a new leader in the PP Soraya instead of Mariano, before a new general elections happens, may ease substantially the big coalition of PSOE, PP and Ciudadanos. But that is not what it's been ask in this forecast.

The developments this week have been interesting (El Pais and other major Spanish papers have the details).   http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2016/02/24/actualidad/1456346160_236195.html?rel=lom Citizens has agreed an acceptable  platform with the Socialists.   This reduces the chances that Podemos is part of a formal coalition (I have already had them at 0% for some time) and is really a gambit to get the PP to abstain during the vote on government formation on March 5th.   It puts the PP in a difficult position.  They had declined the chance to form a government first as they felt it would fail and damage credibility and so wanted the Socialists to try first (and fail).  All along the PP has favoured a unity minority government where the PSOE and C would informally support the PP on a limited set of reforms and new elections late in 2016.  Instead it is now the Socialists who are trying to do exactly this with Sanchez as the leader.  The PP need not vote for Sanchez- merely abstaining will get him in the door.   However, I don't see the PP abstaining and I believe this effort will fail.  
That leaves four scenarios  1) no government, new elections in Spring   2) Rather than the PSOE trying to head a government, it is Ciudadanos that is given the final chance and they are able to form a temporary minority government with votes of PSOE and PP  3)  the PP asks for a turn to form a government, but they depose Rajoy and appoint a new leader in return for an abstention by the PSOE  or 4) The Socialists try to move left and re-attract Podemos into the mix (note it will be difficult to get the support of both Podemos and Ciudadanos).   Note that I don't see either Podemos nor Ciudadanos supporting a formal coalition led by the PP or PSOE- I believe they would at most support a minority government with votes.   My 20 percent probability for Ciudadanos being part of a coaltion is the scenario where Ciudadanos (Rivera) actually heads the minority government.

You and your roommate have a couple who are friends of yours.   They get married.  Your roommate says, "I'll bet you ten bucks they get divorced before Christmas."  You take the bet.  Christmas comes and they are still married.  On Boxing Day, you ask your roomie to pay up.  Your roomie says, "No, I've decided the bet should be extended until they actually get divorced or one of them dies."  You might be excused for never trusting your roommate again. Now that we know this Q is extended into the indefinite future, the entire logic of how to conduct and interpret the research changes.  Presumably those of us who assumed some integrity in the process will be penalized (or rewarded, if we were wrong) when something finally happens.  It is not clear whether this should be attributed to carelessness or sleaziness.  Since there is no actual money on the table, I will assume, as charitably as I can, that the people running this show are just irretrievably dumb.  Meantime, something may happen pretty soon, although it has seemed like that before.

Feb 10: "Spain: Political stalemate in Madrid" --> http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/27b93f7c-ce67-11e5-831d-09f7778e7377.html#axzz3zpwmkpFB The political manoeuvres may seem bewildering and inconsequential to outsiders. Lurking behind the Madrid deadlock, however, are profound challenges that have become alarmingly familiar to policymakers in the rest of Europe and beyond. These range from discontent with the establishment and the rise of populist movements to the decline of the middle class and soaring inequality. They include anger at political corruption and the loss of faith in key institutions, as well as the resurgence of separatist movements and fears over territorial division.
[...]
Just how hard it is to navigate Spain’s political map is clear when considering Mr Sánchez’s options. The Socialists command 90 seats in the 350-seat legislature, their worst result in modern times. To become prime minister, he needs the support or acquiescence of at least two parties and possibly a few more. Mr Sánchez has made clear that his priority is to wrap up a deal quickly with the centrist Ciudadanos party but even that alliance would leave him 46 votes short of a majority. The anti-austerity Podemos movement has challenged the strategy, insisting it will not back Mr Sánchez if he allies with Ciudadanos. The leaders of Ciudadanos, meanwhile, have ruled out any deal with the Socialists that relies on the support of Podemos.
[...]
The result is a heavily fragmented parliament accompanied by paralysing fear and mistrust between the parties. Ciudadanos is painfully aware that its support could be swallowed up by a resurgent PP. The Socialists know that Podemos wants to replace them on the Spanish left and Podemos knows the Socialists will defend their turf. ~~ Feb 10: "Session to name Spain’s next PM may take place in early March" --> http://elpais.com/elpais/2016/02/10/inenglish/1455095838_126960.html Sources close to the Socialist secretary general have said he is planning to hold the investiture debate on the week of February 29 to March 4. This falls within the period of one month that he requested from Congress to seek to build enough consensus for a successful bid. Sánchez has been racing to meet other political leaders in order to find enough common ground for an alliance that could take the form of a full-fledged governing coalition or simply a yes vote, or even abstention, at the investiture session. If Sánchez were to fail, and no other candidate succeeds in getting voted in, Spain would be forced to hold a fresh election later this year.
[...]
Both the PP and anti-austerity party Podemos have been trying to hold the session earlier. Podemos deputies Gloria Elizo and Marcelo Expósito, who sit on the presiding committee, said that “it does not send a good message to citizens when we push back the deadlines and delay the decision sine die, as it creates unnecessary concern.” In the meantime, acting prime minister Mariano Rajoy and his team are working on a document to show Albert Rivera, the leader of emerging party Ciudadanos, when both men hold talks on Thursday. On Friday, Rajoy will take the same material to his scheduled meeting with Sánchez in Congress. The crux of his message will be the convenience of a grand coalition made up of all three parties, which he describes as respectful of the Constitution and “with a moderate agenda.” The PP leader wants to come up with a specific list of proposals that both Sánchez and Rivera could accept ideologically. But the latter two have already been drafting a working paper of their own. ~~~~ COMMENT: If someone has the time, it might actually be fun to play out the different scenarios with game theory. Based on today's news, it seems the only "certain" thing is that there's no way POD and CIUD will be part of the same coalition -- everything else appears to be up in the air!

There is still a long way to go.  At the moment there doesn't seem to be a path through which CUID could be in a governing coalition by itself because the so-called 'grand coalition' (PP, PSOE, CUID) looks unlikely. There is still a small chance that PSOE could from a coalition that includes both POD and CUID, but, given that POD may prefer a new election, it's small. The most likely outcome therefore, is that there is no coalition by the time parliament sits, but that the two mainstream parties will want to avoid another election. PP could therefore be a minority government as long as they got tactical support from PSOE or CUID in parliament. This they could do because they all want to prevent secessionist tendencies from getting even stronger in Spain. Alternatively, new elections may have to be called. There are therefore two paths to the 'None' outcome.

Here's one link that sums up the state of play succinctly: Feb 5: "Spain election: Podemos request sees talks deadlocked" --> http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-35502227 Spain's Socialists (PSOE) have rejected a demand from the anti-austerity Podemos party for exclusive talks to form a new government. The country remains in a political stalemate following December's inconclusive election. On the request of King Felipe VI, PSOE leader Pedro Sanchez has been leading talks with other parties. But Podemos (We Can) leader Pablo Iglesias demanded that he stop speaking with centrist Ciudadanos (Citizens). "Our negotiating team will be ready as soon as the Socialists opt for a government of progress," Reuters quoted him as saying. The move followed a survey on Thursday that showed Podemos would come second in a new national election, overtaking the Socialists. Despite coming first in the election with close to 29% of the vote, acting Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of the conservative Popular Party (PP) lacks the support to form a government. Mr Sanchez said he would continue to talk with all parties except the PP and called for Mr Iglesias to reconsider his demand. The El Pais newspaper quoted him as saying: "There are things that divide us, but one thing unites us all: we have to end the government of Mariano Rajoy and the PP." Mr Sanchez earlier pledged to form a "progressive and reformist" government. Podemos, Ciudadanos and smaller regional parties hold the balance of power in Spanish politics, which has been dominated for decades by the PP and PSOE. If no working government can be formed, a fresh general election will be called. ~~~~ COMMENT: So, as I was saying, it looks like Podemos is holding all the cards. from the latest news; This leaves Sanchez with a choice between a left-wing coalition with Podemos and smaller parties, or a three-way deal with Ciudadanos and the PP. The latter option looks unlikely, as Rajoy and Sanchez have repeatedly ruled out sharing power with one another.  Apparently Rajoy wants to be PM or nothing, so I rule him out.

The latest poll putting Podemos ahead of the PSOE changes everything. It probably nudges Podemos in the direction of wanting new elections. But it also increases the pressure on PSOE to form a government. It increases the pressure on the non-secessionists to get into a coalition. And it makes the PSOE-Podemos disagreement about regional autonomy even more intractable. Can a coalition be formed that includes the PP? Given the very negative feelings towards 'politics as usual' it's hard to see how such a government wouldn't be seen as 'establishment'. Not unless CUID are given a prominent roll and PP are not seen to lead. So a coalition that includes Podemos and CUIT becomes very unlikely; and the desire to avoid a rerun, increases.

This IFP closes in about 2 weeks. I'm operating under the assumption that GJ will NOT extend (again) this IFP's deadline and NEITHER of the parties listed will be part of the government. Further to that, it sounds like Podemos' negotiating position is strengthening (given public opinion), so they might not be in a hurry to agree to a coalition with Sanchez, unless they exact the proverbial pound of flesh.

The Socialistas are probably willing to give up pretty much the whole store to avoid new elections, which recent polls show would result in their coming third behind Podemos.  Unluckily for PSOE, the only ones they can surrender to plausibly are Podemos, who since they will likely do better in new elections have little reason to chat with Sanchez.  None of this is likely to get sorted in the next couple of weeks, one suspects. Well, let's see--the King has asked PSOE to put together a gummint.  PSOE + Podemos is not enough, and Podemos won't play with Ciudadanos, they say.  The regional factions are unlikely to join a formal coalition with PSOE, and vice versa, what with one thing and another.  PSOE says they need at least a month to get sorted. For the people of Spain, this means one thing.  For us it means a somewhat different thing.  If the GJ poobahs stick with the 21 February closing date, the right answer will be Neither, since Sanchez will still be in Chat mode.  If they extend it to allow for reality, all those who thought the original closing date was real will be scrod, or something similarly fishy.  Whatever happens here in Fantasyland, the most likely outcome for Spain is new and similarly inconclusive elections.

We're into the end-game now that the Socialists have been invited to form a coalition. Ciudadanos is too small to be the only partner. Podemos alone only works if the Socialists include regional parties wanting regional autonomy - that is unlikely. There are therefore only two possible outcomes: failure, or a coalition that includes both P and C. I think the attractions of being in power will prove great enough to lead to some kind of agreement.

The only coalition geometry acceptable by both voters and party structures includes, most probably, PSOE, PODEMOS, IU and regional parties, It is clear that i) a big centrist pact is neither popular nor viable; ii) PODEMOS and Ciudadanos are mutually exclusive; iii) the same with PP/Ciudadanos and every autonomist party. In conclusion, either we have PODEMOS in the ruling coalition or no ruling coalition at all, which would mean new elections.

http://openeurope.org.uk/blog/re-run-elections-loom-in-spain-as-little-progress-is-made-in-forming-new-government/ "Pressure is . . . piling up on Sánchez [PSOE] – who seems to be running out of good options quickly. A grand coalition with Rajoy’s Partido Popular (PP) would essentially mean political suicide for PSOE. In addition, a few influential Socialist regional leaders – notably including Andalusia’s Susana Díaz – have categorically rejected an alliance with the anti-establishment Podemos as long as the latter continues to support a binding independence referendum in Catalonia. " . . . this ‘neither PP nor Podemos’ line would make re-run elections inevitable. At that point, Sánchez would likely have to give way to a different Socialist candidate and PSOE may well fare worse than in the 20 December . . .  "Potentially, the ‘third way’ for PSOE could be to abstain in the initial confidence vote and let Rajoy enter office with a minority government. In theory, this would give the Socialists greater influence – as PP would need their support to pass legislation. It would also shield PSOE from accusations of acting irresponsibly by pushing Spain towards re-run elections. However, this option has also been ruled out by PSOE for the time being – and it remains unclear whether Rajoy would agree to anything less than a fully-fledged coalition. More generally, while it would avoid re-run elections, this would hardly be a stable solution in the longer term. Ultimately, even if PSOE abstained from the initial confidence vote, it would face pressure to back Rajoy every time legislation needs to be passed. It is easy to see how such an arrangement could quickly run into trouble. "So far, the main hurdle to an alliance between PSOE and Podemos has been the latter’s willingness to allow a binding independence referendum in Catalonia. Similarly, this appears to be the key reason why Ciudadanos has said that it would vote against any government involving Podemos. However, the political scenario in Catalonia could be changing in the coming weeks – and this might have an impact at the national level. "admittedly very hypothetical – scenario. Podemos could drop its independence referendum ‘red line’ and put greater emphasis on social issues when setting out its conditions for a pact with PSOE. Ciudadanos could then consider abstaining in the initial confidence vote and allow a PSOE-Podemos government to enter office. At the end of the day, all three parties have been campaigning on the need for ‘change’ in Spanish politics. In other words, with the Catalan stumbling block (somewhat) out of the way, perhaps Rajoy’s worst nightmare could start looking like more than just fantasy politics material. "That said, this is all very speculative and several big questions would certainly arise. Would Podemos be prepared to give up on such an important pledge with a new Catalan regional election on the horizon? Why would the party led by Pablo Iglesias want to prop up PSOE, instead of having a go at overtaking them as the main left-wing party in Spain in a re-run general election?
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  If every party is unwilling to move its redline, there will have to be new elections.
If the issue is not resolved after 2 months, a new election is called.

"If that is not forthcoming then King Felipe will be asked to take centre stage as the broker of a deal to form a government.  Should no government be in place on January 13, then the King will select a candidate to take the prime minister’s seat. The King’s choice will then be put to the senate and if his chosen man secures the backing of 176 MPs then Spain will have a new government. If, however, the King’s choice proves unpopular with the senate then the ballot-boxes will be wheeled out once more and the public will be asked to cast its vote for a second time. " . . . incumbent Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy has found friends hard to come by, as one-by-one each party leader has ruled out pacting with the PP. "And so, the PSOE and Sanchez now face the tough choice of allying with a rival or forcing a new election. The PSOE leader has already categorically ruled out a political pact with Mariano Rajoy and the PP . . . . "With business-minded Ciudadanos saying it would abstain in a parliamentary vote, the PSOE have been left with two options: to pact with Podemos or to allow the deadline to pass and risk the possibility of being blamed for a re-election. ". . . .neither option open to him [Sanchez is] extremely attractive.  . . . Despite being openly against new elections, Sanchez will be reluctant to jump into office with Pablo Iglesias and his newly-emerged political powerhouse Podemos.  A large portion of Podemos backers are likely to be former-PSOE voters, who won just 90 seats – their lowest ever total.  Therefore a PSOE-Podemos coalition would likely be popular with the voters. Jan 5: "Spain’s politicians have one week to form a government or risk forcing a second general election" --> http://www.theolivepress.es/spain-news/2016/01/05/spains-politicians-have-one-week-to-form-a-government-or-risk-forcing-a-second-general-election/ THE prospect of a re-election is looking ever more likely, with time running out to form a government before a January 13 cut-off. It has been more than two weeks since the public took to the polls and yet a new government still seems a long way off. A pact between the PSOE, Podemos and Catalan nationalists is now the only option to find a prime minister before that deadline. If that is not forthcoming then King Felipe will be asked to take centre stage as the broker of a deal to form a government. Should no government be in place on January 13, then the King will select a candidate to take the prime minister’s seat. The King’s choice will then be put to the senate and if his chosen man secures the backing of 176 MPs then Spain will have a new government. If, however, the King’s choice proves unpopular with the senate then the ballot-boxes will be wheeled out once more and the public will be asked to cast its vote for a second time. However, up until January 13 Pedro Sanchez and his PSOE party hold the key to power in Spain. With the election producing the first hung parliament since the advent of democracy 40 years ago, incumbent Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy has found friends hard to come by, as one-by-one each party leader has ruled out pacting with the PP. And so, the PSOE and Sanchez now face the tough choice of allying with a rival or forcing a new election. The PSOE leader has already categorically ruled out a political pact with Mariano Rajoy and the PP, following a 45-minute meeting with the acting prime minister. He also said that a second election in the event of no government being formed would be ‘the last option’. With business-minded Ciudadanos saying it would abstain in a parliamentary vote, the PSOE have been left with two options: to pact with Podemos or to allow the deadline to pass and risk the possibility of being blamed for a re-election. It would be fair to say that Sanchez has been shoved between a rock and a hard place, with neither option open to him extremely attractive. Turning to the left to form a government is a profound political choice, likely to divide party members and determine the PSOE’s fate for many years to come. Yet, failing to pact at all will lead to accusations of destabilising the country, as the party will no doubt be blamed for forcing new elections through its refusal to ally. Despite being openly against new elections, Sanchez will be reluctant to jump into office with Pablo Iglesias and his newly-emerged political powerhouse Podemos. The surprise package of the election, Podemos grabbed 69 seats in their first ever general election, changing the face of Spanish politics in the process. A large portion of Podemos backers are likely to be former-PSOE voters, who won just 90 seats – their lowest ever total. Therefore a PSOE-Podemos coalition would likely be popular with the voters.
However, should Sanchez pact, it would not go down so well among his own party members. First of all, Podemos leader Pablo Iglesias is insisting on a Catalan independence referendum as a condition for a deal, which would be difficult for the Socialists to agree to given their current stance against an independent Catalunya. If the PSOE ally with Podemos, they also run the risk of being gobbled up by the fast-growing new party and losing leadership of the left for good. However, they haven’t got much time to make their minds up, as if they are to pact then Sanchez needs to get his skates on, with January 13 approaching ever-so quickly. Whatever happens, compromises will have to be made and a large portion of voters (and politicians) are likely to be unhappy with the outcome. For the good of the country, we can only hope the political uncertainty doesn’t drag on too much longer.

"[Sanchez] failed to halt the centre-left’s slide. Still, for all its electoral travails, the PSOE now finds itself in the paradoxical position of holding the keys to power. Unfortunately for Mr Sánchez, it is hard to see how his party might profit from this privileged position: the Socialists can either join a broad centrist alliance under the leadership of the PP, or attempt to form a leftwing coalition that includes Podemos.
. . . 
"One path seems as improbable as the other, and both are littered with obstacles and risks. A deal with the ruling PP would alienate many Socialist voters, and ensure that Podemos would claim the mantle as the leader of the Spanish opposition. But siding with Podemos would unsettle centrist voters and prompt gasps of shock from Spain’s business community.
“They are in a pretty impossible situation, . . .  “If they strike a deal with Podemos, they lose half their electorate. And if they strike a deal with the PP they lose the other half.” "Doing nothing is not a safe option either. With the momentum swinging towards Podemos in the final days before the December election, there is every risk that a second ballot will see the upstart party overtake the Socialists as the leading force of the Spanish left. Pablo Iglesias, the Podemos leader, rarely misses an opportunity to remind the Socialists of this scenario — making clear that he, unlike Mr Sánchez, has every reason to play hardball in the complex political negotiations that lie ahead. "At a meeting of party leaders this week, the Socialist leader set out his strategy in clear terms: the PSOE would under no circumstances support the re-election of Mariano Rajoy, the current prime minister and PP leader. And it would not seek to form an alliance with Podemos as long as its far-left rival remains committed to an independence referendum in Catalonia, the Spanish region that has been marked by secessionist tensions in recent years. "On substance, his bid to hold the centre ground of Spanish politics met little opposition. The real question, however, is whether he will be allowed to pursue it. Susana Díaz, the Socialist president of Andalusia and Mr Sánchez’s arch-rival inside the party, wants the PSOE to hold a party congress as early as February. That would give her the opportunity to replace him as a leader — either in the midst of coalition talks or, possibly, just months before a snap election. To most outsiders, it seems like a high-risk operation driven largely by personal animosity. There are, at least on the face of it, no discernible ideological differences between the two leaders. “Everyone who now sits down with Pedro Sánchez knows that he may be kicked out the next day. That makes him and his party very weak,” says Professor Pablo Símon, a professor of political sciences at the Carlos III University in Madrid. Even if he prevails against his internal rivals, the damage might already be done. “All the polls show us that Spanish voters punish parties that are divided. If they hold a divisive party congress shortly before [repeat] elections, they are condemned,” adds Prof Símon. Mr Ortega is bleaker still in his assessment: “Starting a succession debate at this moment looks like suicide to me.”

With the election results in, things are starting to become a little more clear. I hope this analysis helps everyone with their probabilities, but keep in mind that I'm still very ignorant of Spanish politics. The sources (see below) answer a question I had for a while: Yes, there can be a minority coalition government. But, any party or coalition must win a vote of confidence in the parliament. If the party/coalition has a majority of seats, then that task is easy. A straightforward party-line vote would do it. If not, the minority coalition can be blocked by the parties that were not invited to form a government. On the first vote, the coalition must win an absolute majority. On the second vote, merely a plurality. So, technically, one or more parties not invited into the government can merely abstain and that should be enough to allow a minority government to form. I rank the scenarios in order of likelihood. It's really just a compilation of the expert opinion and statements of party leaders cobbled together from various sources. It's still highly speculative, though. 1. Deadlock. PP governs alone with Rajoy as president (caretaker government). Likely. This scenario will lead to new elections (likely in March). 2. Coalition of losers. PSOE + Podemos + Popular Unity + regional parties (majority coalition government). Unlikely. Podemos & the Catalan nationalists require a referendum on secession as a precondition to joining a government. Such a referendum is anathema to PSOE's base in southern Spain, which is very much against Catalan secession. PSOE would alienate its voters and future electoral prospects there if they agreed to these terms. For Podemos, joining a government is a bad idea as it would alienate their own base and undermine their goal of replacing PSOE (just as Syriza replaced PASOK) as the major party on the Left. Both PSOE and Podemos have a lot to lose politically. On the other hand, I don't believe Pedro Sanchez has ruled it out. My sense is that the Socialists are eager to rule, so I wouldn't rule out this possibility. 3. PP + Cuidadanos (minority coalition government). Very unlikely. A natural coalition. However, Alberto Rivera has said he would not join a PP-led government because he wanted to avoid the fate of Nick Clegg and the UK's Liberal Party. So, he would rather have his party remain in the opposition. We'll see. If Cuidadanos stands to lose votes to the PP in the next election and PP sweetens the deal, they may relent. This last point is my own speculation. Even if Cuidadanos agrees to join a government, PP still needs the abstention of Podemos or PSOE to form a government. I don't think that will happen. 4. PSOE + Podemos (minority coalition government). Very unlikely. Same reasons as #3. In addition, Cuidadanos has said it will vote against any coalition that includes Podemos. So, this scenario may require the abstention of PP. 5. PSOE + Cuidadanos (minority coalition government) or PSOE + Cuidadanos + Podemos (majority coalition government). Extremely unlikely, Both are unnatural coalitions. For the former, the same reasons as #2. The latter is a mathematically possible majority government that has no realistic chance of happening. Unfortunately, I did not fully realize this until very recently and assigned way too high a probability to the "BOTH" outcome. 5. Grand coalition. PP + PSOE (majority coalition government). Extremely unlikely. Unprecedented. Both the Socialists and Conservatives have a lot to lose from this coalition. The Socialists more so as they will be the junior partner. That scenario would leave Cuidadanos and Podemos as the only alternatives to what is likely to be an unpopular government. Politically, it would be a dream scenario for the two outsider parties that are trying to topple the two-party system. Plus, Sanchez has already ruled it out. Let me know if I've made any errors. Sources: The Wall Street Journal has an excellent rundown of politically realistic scenarios. See http://www.wsj.com/articles/spain-faces-weeks-of-political-instability-after-indecisive-election-1450689973 The France 24 debate features experts who talk about the political constraints on forming any government. See  http://www.france24.com/en/2015-12-21-debate-spanish-reshuffle-part-two Spanish Constitution: https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Spain_2011.pdf (see Section 99, p. 26 for the process of picking a president) On the process of forming a government: http://www.startribune.com/spain-parties-face-tough-talks-after-inconclusive-election/363106711/

The viable options that include Podemos, excluding those with PP due to ideological differences:  (A) PSOE+POD+others 
(B) PSOE+POD+CUID The viable options that include CUID, excluding those with both PP and POD due to ideological differences between the latter two:
(C) PP+CUID+others 
(B) PSOE+POD+CUID  The viable options that include PP: 
(D) PP+PSOE
(E) PP alone + external support from PSOE  ( P(D or E) = 35% + P( inverted D) = 5% ) -- see below for an explanation. 
(C) PP+CUID+others ( P(C)=7% ) The viable options that include PSOE
(A) PSOE+POD+others ( P(A) = 20% ) 
(B) PSOE+POD+CUID (P(B) = 10% )
(F) PSOE+POD with external support from CUID (or vice versa) (P(F) = 10%) Unless I'm missing some possibilities, we can now assign probabilities: 
Starting with the PP ones: 
(C), (D), (E) from among those (D) and (E) might be the most palatable to PP so I expect them to give this a try first – If I were the PSOE, I would not take (D) but may be willing to try out (E) – I’ll give (D) and (E) together a 35% chance of working. Barring that, PP may then try to make (C) work, but that is more difficult: 10% of the remaining 65% -- let’s make it 7%. This leaves 58% to assign.  Now, we go to PSOE trying to form government: 
Their first option (though unlikely) may be to try an inverted (D) followed by (A), then (B) or (F). Let’s give the inverted (D) 10% of the remaining 58%, call it 5%,  (A)  can have 35% of the 58%, call it 20% - and let’s say (F) has half that chance of working, for 10% -- same for (B). This leaves about 13% for a re-election. But that’s not really an option. So we must redistribute to obtain:  P(Neither) = P(D or E) = 46%
P(Both) = P(B) = 12%
P(POD) = P(A or F) =34%
P(CUID) =  P(C) = 8% Finally, we tweak so the probabilities pass the eye-test.

My prediction went stale. I expected that minor parties will undergo the fizz that happened to MoDem or ToPotamos, but polls show the opposite.
The Portuguese elections are somewhat suggestive to what we should expect. Even d'Hondt method of distribution is the same, muddying the numbers from the polls. The only difference is in Spain the four forces are at an arm's length. In Portugal, right-wing parties acknowledged their alliance before the elections, while the left-wing parties took an extremely long time to agree. Should the Portuguese socialists be more effective at alliance-forging, we would have had the equivalent of a POD + PSOE from start; instead, we saw the equivalent of PP + C's for a few days.
In Spain the polls indicate even better scores for the second-tier parties (compare https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ElectionMonthlyAverageGraphPortugal2015.png to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:OpinionPollingSpainGeneralElection2015.png ) suggesting that it will be even more unlikely for either of the two main parties to govern alone. So I am giving the NONE option a very small chance.
One one hand, the left binomial sums a bit higher than the right. On the other, the d'Hondt method favors the largest party, thus helping the PP+C's, where the smaller partner is less important. I am going out on a limb by thinking that d'Hondt-based redistribution will squash the 2-4% advantage the PSOE+POD have.
In summary, I am revising up both "one party" options, and down "none".

Talky analysis: https://www.fxstreet.com/news/forex-news/article.aspx?storyid=9afdc3b5-1fd3-4936-81dd-5822f0727e70 In short, the mathematically and politically feasible options: 
(I-A) Minority Government lead by PP
(I-B) Minority Government lead by PSOE
(I-C) Minority Government lead by C's 
(II-A) Coalition of PP and C's (may or may not be sufficient, looks borderline)
(II-B) Coalition of PSOE, C's and Podemos There has never been a coalition in Spain, but there has never been a multi-party situation in Spain. Let's assign 60% to all options in (I) and 40% to those in (II).
Among the ones in (I), (I-A) is most likely considering PP are leading in the seat projections by some distance, however this is contingent on the support of PSOE from the outside or C's and others from the outside. (I-B) is contingent on PSOE being second and securing support from POD and C's. (I-C) is contingent on some bizarre arrangement that is probably unlikely. 
Assigning these 3 events prob's of 60, 30, 10 respectively (conditioned on (I) ). 
(II-A)  is contingent on these two having enough seats to make it work, and on C's changing their rhetoric about joining a coalition. Giving this a 70% chance (conditioned on II) .
(II-B) requires 3 parties to agree, giving this a 30% chance (conditioned on II).  Finally, adjusting down to factor in the crowd's position.

Five most recent polls (http://www.electograph.com/) have PP ahead. But, as we've seen with this year's elections in Spain, Poland, Greece, the UK, and Israel, the polls can be wrong. My sense is that they will be wrong again. But I have no idea how they will be wrong. Therefore, I am just giving even odds to PP, PSOE and CUI (33%-34% each). My relatively high probability for "Both" anticipates a CUI victory that leads to a CUI+POD coalition (20%). After all, if CUI won, why would they dilute their mandate by picking one of the discredited establishment parties as a junior partner (unless they had no other choice)? So, I'm giving only a 10% chance that CUI forms a coalition with either PP or PSOE alone. Also, a surprise PSOE victory could lead to a coalition with POD alone, CUI alone, or with POD and CUI. I'm giving even odds for each of these outcomes (10% each). A victory by PP would almost certainly result in a PP+CUI coalition (30%). I could be wrong, but I believe PP and PSOE have all but ruled out a grand coalition (1% probability). Since the chances of a landslide victory (155 to >175 seats) by any one of the top three parties are very low (~3% each), that means the probability of a "Neither" outcome should be low, as well.

I've been trying to improve my estimate of the likelihood of a coalition government. The key question, given the current opinion polls, could either PSOE or PP govern alone, as a minority? Before I just guessed 60%, making a hand-wavy comparison to the UK in 2010 (although, I still think the comparison is valid).  Minority governments have worked in Spain because it's hard to get a vote of no confidence through (you need to propose an alternative candidate, too), and PSOE, who ran them most recently, could rely upon several similar small parties to support them on a vote-by-vote basis. This suggests a coalition is likely, as this time around, due to the electoral maths, it is unlikely that any one party will hold enough seats to be able to do the same thing. Any party regularly contributing a significant chunk of votes is surely going to want to be part of the government, setting the agenda. Hence, I've moved my probability of a coalition up to 70%. However, on the no side, coalition building is somewhat fraught, and it could just result in multiple elections until there is a clear winner. While this has happened in other European countries, my initial guess is that Spain is too big for this to happen, but I might revisit this. I think something that might be weighing upon the smaller parties, particularly CUID, is the cautionary tale of the Lib Dems in the UK, who were punished electorally this year. Taking a closer look at the polling data, and how it translates into seats, PSOE would need both POD and CUID to get a majority, while PP would just need CUID. Hence, I'm now discounting the probability of POD solely being in a coalition. Otherwise probabilities are in line with bookie odds and probability of coalition, as per my original prediction. See original post for fuller rationale: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/32553 Efficacy of Spanish minority government performance source: http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1450196 Spanish poll of polls source: http://www.electograph.com/p/electograph-poll-of-polls.html

How likely is a coalition at all? A significant fact is that there has never been a coalition government in Spanish politics since the transition to democracy in the late 70s. When insufficient votes exist, parties have prefered to run minority governments. However, this election is unprecedentedly tight, with opinion polls putting the big parties with only 55% of the vote between them, as opposed to ~80% of the vote in the past.  A minority government with ~30% of the vote would struggle, although other sorts of deals could be made, that while not formally in a coalition, parties with shared priorities could vote together. To be honest, I don't know enough about Spanish politics to translate this into a good probability yet, but this looks enough like what happened in the UK General Election in 2010 to make me think a coalition has a more than even chance - 60%.  This is something I will try revisit in future forecasts, along with any changes that might occur in the opinion polling. For example there could be a consolidation around the major parties, after people have been flirting with other candidates. Next, to work out the probabilities of possible coalition membership, I'm using betting odds for most seats in the Congress of Deputies as to which party will be the senior partner, and hence which of these two parties are likely to be a junior party. As of today, 1 November, the bookies' odds have it ~82% that the currently ruling Partido Popular (PP) will get the most votes, and hence will more likely be in a position to form a coalition. Again, something to keep an eye on in the future. Podemos (POD), being anti-austerity and indeed starting due to the unpopularity of PP's policies, are unlikely to shack up with them. The Ciudadanos (CUID) on the other hand, while more centrist than the PP, are mostly focused on opposing the Catalan nationalists. Hence, provided the PP agree to impede the independence movement, CUID could join them. A further argument in favour of CUID joining a coalition would be that the leader was apparently affiliated with the PP prior to joining the CUID. Hence, 82% of 60% is the 49% chance of CUID joining a PP-led coalition. On the other hand, the Partido Socialista Obrero Español (PSOE), the other main party have enough in common with POD ideologically that they could work together. And given PSOE's preference for devolution to regions, it's unlikely that the CUID would be keen on working with them, despite shared stated policies. I'm less sure of that last factor, but for now I'm going with the 18% of 60% being a 11% chance of POD joining a PSOE-led coalition. I might split this, to allow for a coalition with both in it.
